In the '60s and '70s, rock climbers started doing things that until then were thought to be impossible: scurrying up routes like the 4,700-foot face of Half Dome in Yosemite without hammering in metal spikes, called pitons, as anchors.
They relied only on their own strength and the protection of removable bolts to hold safety ropes.
Today, it's the standard climbing technique.
Last month, adventurer Kurt Albert, one of the pioneers of this style of climbing, died from a fall.
His memorial service was held yesterday in his home country of Germany.
Outdoors writer Mark Jenkins joins us now.
Mark, welcome to the program.
Thanks a lot, Rebecca.
What would you say is Kurt Albert's contribution to the world of climbing?
He'll be remembered for developing the term red point.
And to red point a route is to never hang on pitons, to never hang on your equipment.
It's simply to climb the entire route using only your feet and your hands.
And how unusual was that when he pioneered it?
For the area that he was living in, it was very unusual.
People would often put in pitons and then hang off of them.
And he came back from East Germany after traveling there and realized that free climbing was the future of climbing, and he was right about that.
In the next 30 years, climbing changed dramatically, where the red point became the yardstick by which was measure a climber's performance.
